edu.ucsf.ModelSelector

Class ModelSelectorLauncher

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ucsf.ModelSelector.ModelSelectorLauncher

  • public class ModelSelectorLauncher
extends java.lang.Object
    Runs all-subsets model selection. Models are linear and are to predict response variables for a set of samples using predictors from a set of rasters. Models are vetted using cross validation.
    Author:
    Joshua Ladau, jladau@gmail.com

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors

      ModelSelectorLauncher()

    • Constructor Detail

      • ModelSelectorLauncher

        public ModelSelectorLauncher()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] rgsArgs)
        Writes file giving the best model for each number of predictors. In output file, each row represents a selected model. Columns give:

        1. number of predictors,
        2. cross validation r^2 (1-PRESS/TSS)
        3. PRESS statistic
        4. r^2
        5. adjusted r^2
        6. flag for whether the model is the best for the specified response variable
        7. response variable
        8. predictors
        9. parameter estimates and paths to rasters with each predictor
        10. date used for training data if different from date in BIOM file
        11. vert used for training data if different from date in BIOM file (defaults to 0).
        12. path to BIOM file.
        Parameters:
        Arguments - pass as --{argument name}={argument value}. Name-value pairs are:

        Required arguments

        • sBIOMPath [string] = Absolute path to a file containing an OTU table. File should be in BIOM format (HDF5). Should include 'latitude', 'longitude', 'datetime', and optionally 'vert' sample metadata fields.

        • sRasterListPath [string] = Absolute path to file containing list of paths of rasters to consider. Rasters should be in NetCDF format. File should contain absolute paths, one path per line, with no header. The name of the variable to use in each raster can be specified after each path, delimited by a comma. If no variables are specified, the first variable in each raster will be used.

        • sResponseVarsListPath [string] = Path to file with list of names of variables to model. Specific observations can be listed, or use 'Richness', 'Shannon', and 'AllTaxa' to model richness, Shannon diversity, and all taxa in BIOM file, respectively.

        • sOutputPath [string] = Path write output to. Output written in comma-delimited format.

        Optional arguments

        • sSampleMetadataPath [string] [OPTIONAL] = Path to text file containing sample metadata formatted according to http://biom-format.org/documentation/adding_metadata.html. For use if BIOM file does not contain metadata. Must include 'id', 'datetime' and 'latitude', 'longitude' or 'x','y' fields

        • sSamplesToKeepPath [string] [OPTIONAL] = Path to file with list of samples to keep. File should contain a list of sample names, one per line.

        • sObservationsToKeepPath [string] [OPTIONAL] = Path to file with list of observations to keep. File should contain a list of observation names.

        • bCheckRarefied [boolean] [OPTIONAL] = Flag for whether to check for rarefaction. If enabled and table is not rarefied, error will be thrown. Default is true.

        • iRarefactionTotal [integer] [OPTIONAL] = Total count to which to rarefy samples.

        • sTrainingDate [string] [OPTIONAL] = Date (YYYY-MM-DD) to be used for loading training values. If this argument is unspecified, date of sample collection is used.

        • dTrainingVert [double] [OPTIONAL] = Elevation to be used for loading training values. Defaults to 0.

        • iMaxPredictors [integer] [OPTIONAL] = Maximum number of predictors to consider for models. Defaults to the total number of predictors.

        • sResponseTransform [string] = Transform to use for response variable. Supported values are 'logit' and 'identity'. The former transformation is appropriate for response variables bounded by 0 and 1. Defaults to 'logit'. Richness and Shannon diversity response variables are always log transformed.
